content: waistcoat stitch stocking written by carmen jacob 2016 notes uses approx 7oz of worsted weight yarn & a 6mm hook waistcoat technique to obtain the knit-like stockinette appearance pictured all scs are made into the verticals the v of the stitch below this is called waistcoat or split single_crochet if you use traditional single_crochet the finished project will probably be a bit larger and looser waistcoat stitch also tends to lean slightly blocking will minimize this appearance print this page to design the colorwork of your stocking toe *all rounds are closed with an invisible join remove hook from working loop insert it through both top loops of the first stitch from the back then pull your working loop through so it is at the back of your work you do not chain 1 just go right into next round after your join round 1 10 single_crochet in a magic_ring round 2 1 single_crochet into first stitch below 2 single_crochet in next repeat for rest of round 15 round 3 1 single_crochet into each stitch 15 round 4 1 single_crochet into first 2 stitches 2 single_crochet in next repeat for rest of round 20 round 5 1 single_crochet into each stitch 20 round 6 1 single_crochet into first 3 stitches 2 single_crochet in next repeat for rest of round 25 round 7 1 single_crochet into each stitch 25 round 8 1 single_crochet into first 4 stitches 2 single_crochet in next repeat for rest of round 30 round 9 1 single_crochet into each stitch 30 round 10 1 single_crochet into first 5 stitches 2 single_crochet in next repeat for rest of round 35 round 11 1 single_crochet into each stitch 35 round 12 1 single_crochet into first 6 stitches 2 single_crochet in next repeat for rest of round 40 foot rounds 13 - 33 1 single_crochet into each stitch below 40 heel the heel is worked in row decreasing on both sides to form a triangle *waistcoat row cannot be turned in the normal fashion you must remove your hook leave your working loop unfinished use a stitch marker or safety pin to keep it from sinking down and unraveling pull your yarn all the way over to the beginning of the next row draw up a loop through the top of the first stitch and then begin your new row making sure to stitch over the loose yarn in the back when you reach the end of each row just pick up the unfinished loop before you pull through on your final stitch & then move your marker to the new loop if you have trouble with this ^ technique you can either tie-off each row or use traditional single_crochet for the heel for a different texture row 1 single_crochet into 20 stitches 20 row2 decrease single_crochet into next 16 stitches decrease 18 row 3 decrease single_crochet into next 14 stitches decrease 16 row 4 decrease single_crochet into next 12 stitches decrease 14 row 5 decrease single_crochet into next 10
